issues.description: Whether the district court erred in denying a preliminary injunction against New York's prohibition on carrying firearms in 'sensitive locations' (Times Square, NYC subway, Metro-North rail system) under the Second Amendment.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found a robust historical tradition of regulating firearms in crowded public places, and analogized Times Square and public transit to such locations, concluding the challenged restrictions are consistent with the Second Amendment.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in denying a preliminary injunction against New York's ban on open carry of firearms.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that historical tradition allows states to ban one mode of carry (open or concealed) so long as the other is permitted, and New York's ban on open carry is consistent with that tradition.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in denying a preliminary injunction against New York City's requirement that state concealed carry license holders obtain a city-specific permit to carry in the City.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found a strong historical tradition of localities imposing their own, sometimes stricter, gun regulations, and held that the city permit requirement is presumptively constitutional and not shown to be unduly burdensome.

key_precedents: N.Y. State Rifle & Pistol Ass’n, Inc. v. Bruen, 597 U.S. 1 (2022)
District of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. 570 (2008)
McDonald v. City of Chicago, 561 U.S. 742 (2010)
Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7 (2008)
summary_text: Plaintiffs-Appellants brought pre-enforcement Second Amendment challenges to certain aspects of New York State’s (“New York” or the “State”) concealed carry license regime. As relevant to this appeal, Plaintiffs challenge the constitutionality of: (1) the prohibition on carrying firearms in “sensitive locations”—namely, Times Square, the New York City (the “City”) subway system, and the Metro-North rail system, see N.Y. Penal Law §§ 265.01-e(2)(t), (2)(n); (2) New York’s ban on open carry, see id. § 400.00(15); and (3) the requirement that a State concealed carry license holder apply for and receive a City-specific permit in order to carry a firearm in the City, see id. § 400.00(6). Plaintiffs filed a motion to preliminarily enjoin the enforcement of those provisions, which the district court denied in a March 13, 2023 order. On this appeal from that order, we conclude that Plaintiffs are unlikely to succeed on the merits because, based on the preliminary record before us, the government has demonstrated that each of the challenged provisions falls within our Nation’s historical tradition of gun regulations and, thus, does not violate the Second Amendment. Accordingly, we AFFIRM the order of the district court.
